key_points: Colin Powell, the first Black US secretary of state and former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died from complications of Covid-19 at age 84.
His family confirmed he was fully vaccinated but had multiple myeloma, a type of cancer that suppresses the immune system, and Parkinson's disease.
Powell had a distinguished career, serving in both Gulf and Vietnam Wars, and held significant positions in the U.S. government across Republican administrations.
He was considered a potential presidential candidate in the mid-90s but was criticized for his role in pushing faulty intelligence that led to the Iraq War.
Powell became disillusioned with the rightward shift of the Republican Party and endorsed Democrat Barack Obama for president.
He is survived by his wife, Alma Vivian Powell, and three children. Alma Powell also tested positive for Covid-19 but exhibited only mild symptoms.
Over 7,000 breakthrough Covid-19 cases resulting in death have been reported in fully vaccinated individuals in the U.S.

Leaders, including President Joe Biden, former Vice President Dick Cheney, and former Secretary of States Madeleine Albright and Condoleezza Rice, mourned Powell's death, highlighting his legacy and public service.
Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin described Powell as a personal friend and mentor, praising his leadership and patriotism.
Born to Jamaican immigrants in Harlem, New York, Powell's military career began after graduating from the City College of New York where he participated in ROTC.
